title: Italian corvette Vettor Pisani
text:
Vettor Pisani was a <a href="screw%20corvette">screw corvette</a> of the Italian (Royal Navy) built in the late 1860s and early 1870s. The ship left Italy in 1882 for a three-year <a href="Circumnavigation">voyage round the world</a>.
Design.
The design for "Vettor Pisani" was prepared by the naval engineer <a href="Giuseppe%20Micheli">Giuseppe Micheli</a>. "Vettor Pisani" was <a href="length%20between%20perpendiculars">long between perpendiculars</a>, and she had a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and an average <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . She <a href="displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> . She had a crew of 226.
Her propulsion system consisted of a single <a href="marine%20steam%20engine">marine steam engine</a> that drove a single <a href="screw%20propeller">screw propeller</a>. Steam was supplied by a pair of coal-fired <a href="fire-tube%20boiler">fire-tube boiler</a>s that were manufactured by the firm Guppy of <a href="Naples">Naples</a>. "Vettor Pisani" could steam at a top speed of from . To supplement the steam engines, she was fitted with a <a href="full%20ship%20rig">full ship rig</a>.
The <a href="main%20battery">main battery</a> for "Vettor Pisani" consisted of six <a href="muzzle-loading%20gun">muzzle-loading gun</a>s, three guns per <a href="Broadside%20%28naval%29">broadside</a>. For close-range defense against <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a>s, she initially carried a <a href="battleship%20secondary%20armament">secondary battery</a> of two guns, two guns, and two guns. During a refit in 1879, she was rearmed with a main battery of ten 120 mm <a href="breech-loading%20gun">breech-loading gun</a>s. Four of these guns were removed in 1885.
Service history.
The ship was <a href="keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 11 May 1867 in the Venice Naval Yard, under the name "Briosa". While still under construction in 1868, she was renamed "Vettor Pisani", and her completed <a href="hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a> was <a href="ship%20launching">launched</a> on 22 July 1869. <a href="Fitting%20out">Fitting out</a> was completed by 10 April 1871. After entering service, "Vettor Pisani" was sent on a cruise abroad, and later in 1871, she had reached Japanese waters. She remained abroad the following year, and during the voyage she visited Australia and New Guinea. She was still in Australian waters in 1873. The ship was modernized in 1879.
"Vettor Pisani" embarked on a lengthy voyage overseas in the early 1880s with a variety of goals, including training the crew, <a href="show%20the%20flag">showing the flag</a>, and conducting extensive scientific experiments. These tests included <a href="hydrographic%20survey">hydrographic survey</a>s, depth soundings, and collection of marine animals for later study. A temporary laboratory was set up in the gun battery deck. The ship's captain was Commander <a href="Giuseppe%20Palumbo%20%28admiral%29">Giuseppe Palumbo</a> for the duration of the voyage. Lieutenants Cesare Marcacci and Gaetano Chierchia were responsible for supervising most of the experiments, and Chierchia had been sent to study at the <a href="Stazione%20Zoologica">Zoological Station at Naples</a> for three months before the trip. <a href="Anton%20Dohrn">Anton Dohrn</a>, the director of the facility, came aboard "Vettor Pisani" to discuss the expedition before the vessel sent sail, and he later welcomed the ship home. The ship departed from Naples on 20 April 1882.
"Vettor Pisani" conducted surveys off the coast of South America, including around the <a href="Chonos%20Archipelago">Chonos Archipelago</a> between 23 November and 6 December 1882. Later, during an exploration of the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Corcovado">Gulf of Corcovado</a>, "Vettor Pisani" <a href="ran%20aground">ran aground</a> twice but her crew was able to free the vessel at <a href="high%20tide">high tide</a> both times. While there, the captain named several islands that had previously not been named. In early 1883, "Vettor Pisani" visited <a href="Valparaiso">Valparaiso</a>, Chile; from there, she sailed to <a href="Coquimbo">Coquimbo</a> and then <a href="Caldera%2C%20Chile">Caldera</a>, where she conducted extensive surveys of the coast, which had been dangerous for merchant vessels due to insufficient charts. In March 1884, she arrived in the <a href="Gal%C3%A1pagos%20Islands">Galápagos Islands</a>, where she conducted further tests. "Vettor Pisani" then crossed the Pacific, conducting additional surveys along the way, including near the <a href="Hawaiian%20Islands">Hawaiian Islands</a>.
While still overseas later in 1884, "Vettor Pisani" was sent to East Asian waters to reinforce the Italian presence there, which at that time consisted of the screw corvette , during a period of tension that resulted in the <a href="Sino-French%20War">Sino-French War</a>. "Vettor Pisani" arrived back in Italy on 29 April 1885, having collected some 1,600 specimens over the course of the voyage. Later that year, she was reduced to a <a href="training%20ship">training ship</a> for <a href="naval%20cadet">naval cadet</a>s at the Italian naval academy in <a href="Livorno">Livorno</a>. She served in this capacity until the early 1890s, and on 12 February 1893, the Italian navy discarded the ship. Her ultimate fate is unknown.
